1.48: These SWSs act as an effective layer with refractive index gradually changing from n=1 (air) to n=1.48 (borosilicate glass), as shown in Fig. 4, effectively suppressing the reflection in this interface and showing a broadband anti-reflective property.

2.4961: For example, the Δτd,rsw of coating V is reduced by the refractive index of the anatase TiO2 coating (n = 2.4961 at 589.3 nm [53]), which exceeds that of soda-lime glass (n = 1.5232 [54]).
1.5232: For example, the Δτd,rsw of coating V is reduced by the refractive index of the anatase TiO2 coating (n = 2.4961 at 589.3 nm [53]), which exceeds that of soda-lime glass (n = 1.5232 [54]).

1.23: To suppress the Fresnel reflections at the interface between air and solar glass, an ideal single-layer AR coating with a quarter-wavelength optical thickness has a refractive index of 1.23 [4–6], which need to introduce a certain porosity, around 55%, into a dense material in nature (e.g., silica) according to the effective medium theory [7].

1.13: Jiang et al. [15] reported the double-layer AR coatings with superhydrophobic surfaces, in which the top layer was an organically modified silicate thin film with an ultralow refractive index of 1.13.

1.3: The reflective index was measured using a reflective film thickness monitor (Otsuka Electronics, FE-3000), and the refractive index of the coating was shown to be 1.3 at 589.3nm, which allowed the coating to act as an anti-reflection layer.

1.5: The solar covers used as protective glass in PV panels are made up of a low iron toughened glass of refractive index ∼1.5, where about 4% of light falling is reflected from the top cover glass in a PV module [6].
